newsitem.title: UK: SOCCER-EVERTON DENY LIVERPOOL TOP SPOT WITH LATE EQUALISER.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-EVERTON DENY LIVERPOOL TOP SPOT WITH LATE EQUALISER.

text.p: Liverpool squandered a chance to go to the top of the English premier league on Wednesday when they allowed Everton to snatch a 1-1 draw with a late equaliser.
Gary Speed struck for Everton with eight minutes remaining after England striker Robbie Fowler had scored a first-half goal against the team he supported as a boy.
The result meant Liverpool stayed in second place on 27 points, a point behind Newcastle. Everton leapfrog over Tottenham into seventh, seven points behind their neighbours.
Rbbie Fowler put Liverpool ahead on the half-hour, heading home a fine cross from Jamie Rednapp for his ninth goal in seven goals since his return from injury.
But Everton, who put seven goals past Southampton at the weekend, fought back after the interval to stop Liverpool in their tracks with a goal from a set-piece.
Andy Hinchcliffe swung in a freekick and Speed, who signed for the club from Leeds for 3.5 million pounds ($5.9 million) in the close season, powered a header beyond Liverpool 'keeper David James.

"We had a good first half where we matched them pace for pace, then set the tempo," Liverpool manager Roy Evans said. "But in the second half we lost the plot. We are just forgetting to pass the ball at the moment."
To compound Liverpool's frustration, England forward Steve McManaman limped off with a hamstring strain after just 17 minutes.
He was replaced by Stan Collymore, the subject of speculation over a possible move to Aston Villa earlier this week.
